content: The "Saving the Earnings and Noting the Investment of Our Retired Seniors Act of 2015" or the "SENIORS Act of 2015" aims to ensure that seniors, especially those on fixed incomes, receive proper cost-of-living increases in their social security benefits. Congress should work with relevant agencies to develop a legislative solution that adequately reflects beneficiaries' needs. The "SENIORS Act of 2015" aims to ensure seniors on fixed incomes receive proper cost-of-living increases in social security benefits. SEC. 3 proposes a one-time supplementary payment to beneficiaries of social security and veterans benefits. The "SENIORS Act of 2015" proposes a one-time payment to individuals eligible for specific benefit payments or SSI cash benefits. The curr_chunk describes monthly insurance benefits under the Social Security Act, railroad retirement benefits under the Railroad Retirement Act, and veterans benefits administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The curr_chunk describes SSI cash benefits payable under title XVI of the Social Security Act, including increases in rates made under the Veterans' Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act of 2014 and benefit amounts payable under title II of the Social Security Act. The curr_chunk explains the timing and manner of SSI cash benefit payments under title XVI of the Social Security Act. Payments must be made within 120 days of the Act's enactment, and individuals are only eligible for one payment under this section. Additionally, payments are not made if the individual passes away before certification for the benefit. The Secretary of the Treasury can electronically disburse payments to individuals within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Written notice must be provided to recipients explaining the one-time benefit increase. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with relevant agencies, must publish information on eligibility, distribution timeframe, and other details regarding payments authorized under this subsection on a public website. No payments can be disbursed after December 31, 2016. The Commissioner of Social Security, Railroad Retirement Board, and Secretary of Veterans Affairs certify individuals for payments under this section. Payments are not considered taxable income. Payments made under this section are not considered taxable income and are protected from assignment under specific provisions. The payment under subsection (a) shall be made to the individual's representative payee or fiduciary for the benefit of the entitled individual. Applicability includes payments based on specified benefits in the same manner as under title II or XVI of the Social Security Act. The payment under subsection (a) will be made to the individual's representative payee or fiduciary for the benefit of the entitled individual. Payment on the basis of a railroad retirement benefit and veterans benefit will be subject to specific sections of the respective Acts. The payment amount is described in this subsection. The payment amount for individuals entitled to specific benefit payments or SSI cash benefits is 12 percent of the amount payable for November 2015. Appropriations are made for administrative costs to carry out this section for fiscal years 2016 through 2017. The Commissioner of Social Security and the Railroad Retirement Board will receive necessary funds for payments to eligible individuals and administrative expenses related to this section. The Retirement Board and the Department of Veterans Affairs will receive necessary funds for payments to eligible individuals and administrative expenses related to this section. Individuals entitled to benefit payments described in subsection (a)(1)(B)(iii) are authorized under subsection (a)(1)(A). SEC. 4. OFFSETS. All balances under the "United States Enrichment Corporation Fund" are permanently rescinded. No amounts can be rescinded from emergency requirements designated by Congress. An amendment requires taxpayers to include their Social Security Number to claim the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit. The amendment requires taxpayers to include their Social Security Number on tax returns to claim the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit. This requirement also applies to joint returns, where either spouse's social security number can be used. There is a limitation on this requirement if the tentative minimum tax exceeds the credit allowed. Omissions of the correct social security number are treated as mathematical or clerical errors. Amendments were made to section 24(e) of the Code regarding the Identification Requirement for Qualifying Children. Funds from the Making Home Affordable Program and DOE ATVM Loan Program are being rescinded. Effective date for the amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015. Rescission of unobligated funds for the DOE ATVM Loan Program from the Consolidated Security, Disaster Assistance, and Continuing Appropriations Act, 2009. SEC. 5. REPORT. Within 1 year of this Act's enactment, heads of SSA, Railroad Retirement Board, VA, and Labor Dept. must jointly submit a report to Congress with a legislative solution for Social Security cost-of-living adjustments.
